text: Bottle: Pours a murky brown with a big tan head. Aroma, smoky with some dark fruits. Flavor, fruity, some smoky notes, and some caramel malts. Solid, and well balanced.

What to expect from a traditional ale?  Nice, tan frothy head over a dark mahogany body.  Smokey, definetely.  Thats probably its most striking character.  It also has a lot of earthiness, with medium maltiness.  Very full flavor.  There is a little more alcohol in the nose than I would generally like, which surprises me since its not that high in ABV.

Hazy amber pour, with a gigantic off-white head - wonderfully woody and smokey aroma, much like schlenkerla, with juniper very subdued, some biscuity malt, earthy, leathery notes - soft mouthfeel - quite dry, with mineral/chalk notes - the smoke is not as prominent as the aroma suggests, nor is the juniper - smoke and wood combine with the dry, earthy qualities to give the beer a charcoal-like character that is not entirely pleasant - an interesting mix of spices near the end, plus something else, lurking far in the background.......WORMWOOD! - good lord, why? - sure, theres only a little bit, but even that is too much - the beer was doing so well, but this wormwood taste lingering on my tongue is starting to kill the experience.

(50cl, bottled 3/07) Enormous tan head fills the glass, eventually revealing a lightly hazed ruby body.  Aroma is medium sweet, smoked wood, light juniper.  Taste is medium sweet, wood, some caramel, earthy, berry, smoke/burnt, light sourness.  Soft, light-medium body.

200ml taster from bottle. Pours a russet body colour under a thin tan cap. Firm lacing on the glass. Woody and earthy smell with notes of moderate smokiness. Flavour got a brush of juniper berry and a blend of spicy malts followed by dark fruits. Slightly yeasty bitterness towards the end (Tromsø Ølfestival, 15.08.2007).

Bottle at GBBF 2007.  Hazy pale chestnut with thick lasting beige head.  Good smoke and a little herby, its got vegetables.  But it settles down and is a good hoppy smoky beer.  Almost like a best bitter.  Nice intense hop.  Bit over carbonated.  Quite a fresh aroma.  Just a little harsh from carbonation.  Still, some smoke over it all.  Loads going on . Grassy hop aroma.

Poured hazy brown with a nice head. smokey and earthy aromas. (pork, spice, and yeast). im generally not a huge fan of smoked beers but this was very nicely balanced.  smoked flavors blended nicely with the juniper. pretty enjoyable

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 Rating #500.  500ml bottle at Uber Tavern in Seattle.  Pour is a murky reddish brown with a nice off white head, which lasted almost the entire beer.  Aroma is smoke (charcoal) and spiciness - earthy , pine and berries.  Taste is a perfect representation of the aroma - the smoke, earthiness, sweet berries and spice blend very nicely together.  Had the perfect ratebeer experience for rating #500 - drinking with a new friend (after4ever) who I met through the site, at a bar (Uber) that I learned about through the site and drinking a beer I would have never tried had it not been for this site.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Bottle.
Pours a deep murky brown with a robust tan head. The aroma is sweet and malty, ample smoke, almost like honey-baked ham. Loads of smoky oak in the flavor, warm nutty malts, a mild twist of lemon zest, juniper that comes on hard in the finish and lingers with a metallic juniper bitterness that still bites into the tongue an hour later. Nice body, balanced mouthfeel. A complex and interesting beer that I find more intriguing than outright delightful. In the end, this one is like the other juniper-based beers Ive had: the bitterness is not nearly as pleasant as what one gets from hops.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at GBBF. Cloudy mid brown with an off white head. Good looking beer. Extremely grassy hop nose with some malty undertones. Lovely oaky earthyness with some tangy malt to the flavour. Reasonably complex. A little over carbed.

Doing this one from memory. Pours out dark brown color, almost black with a HUGE brown head. Aroma was some oak notes, roasted nuts, and smoke flavor. Taste is very roasted with some light coffee and nuts going on then a nice smokey flavor kicking in at the end. I actually liked the aftertaste better than the full flavor because the smokiness became lighter and the roasted nuts blend together for a nice finish. Good stuff.

Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured black color with a large frothy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate roasted coffee and dark fruit and woody smoke aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Solid dark roasted flavor with medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid complex beer.

Bottled - GBBF 2007.  A hazy brown coloured beer with a nice off-white coloured head.  The aroma is smoky and peaty with hints of seaweed.  The taste is very dry and smoky.  More peat and quite vegetal.  Odd but interesting.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2008 Bottle courtesy of Ross.  Pours brown and opaque with a nice fizzy white head.  Smells of juniper berries, hints of campfires, lots of gin like qualities, some underlying sweet malt.  Tastes of smoked malt, pepper, juniper berries, lots of bitterness.  Some chocolatey touches are also present.  Mouthfeel is full.  Finish is lightly smoky and bitter.  Very interesting in a good way!

Hints of jerky, wood, smoke. Great smell. I love the smoked ale a lot. Great aroma. An odd hazy, cloudy, and dark caramel color. A very ood color, but a different color tha is nice. A little too carbonated if you ask me. The wood, smoke, and jerky flavor are definitely noticeable. There are not really any sweet notes to the beer. I feel like I am drinking a beer that was smoked. Decent flavor, this beer is very smokey and woody. Nothing more to say other than this beer is very straightforward with the label. On the thin side which is kind of annoying.

Bottle... Murky, caramel-colored ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Excellent retention. The aroma is of hickory smoke and juniper berries.... I gotta say it... Christmas on fire! I told myself I wouldnt say it... but there it is... all laid out... its even bolded. Fascinating flavor. Its all smoke and acid and moderate, earthy bitterness. Medium-bodied and watery with fizzy carbonation. Thin, smoky finish! Thanks to mgumby10 or boboski for bringing this crazy beer down from Orlando!

pours an opaque dark brown with a huge foamy tan head.  aroma is moderately smoked with notes of pineapple.  flavor is sweet up front with a juicy, fruity flavor of grapes and berries and a hint of chocolate.  the smoke shows up in the aftertaste and lingers around.  just the right amount of smoke.  the berries go well with the dry smoky aftertaste.  good stuff.

500ml Bottle:  Complex aroma.  Smells of juniper, piny hops, smoke, roasted malts, chocolate, and black pepper.  Poured medium to dark brown in color with a foamy, creamy, light brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Flavor is a little sweet and a little bitter.  Tastes of malts, smoke, burnt malt, roasting, chocolate, a little juniper, a little piny hops, and a tiny bit of mint.  Medium body.  Thickish, dryish texture.  Fizzy carbonation.  Burnt malty finish.  Overall, over carbonated and too burnt.  Tastes like you pull some burnt wood out of the fire and suck on it.

Pours a slighly cloudy deep ruby red color with large tan head. Aroma has subtle, oily, slightly pungent smoke, faint note of vanilla, warm cherries, and a touch of bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is fairly malty, slightly acidic, pretty woody, bit of caramel and vanilla, with a mildly bitter, faintly metallic finish. An interesting brew overall

Pours a light, cloudy, caramel brown with a small light tan head.  As boboski would say, "Christmas on fire."  Alot of smoky malt, funky carmael, and some roast in there all mixed in one.  Really unique aroma.  The taste was much the same.  Big funky smoke flavors, some mild bitterness, and maybe just a touch of some citrus.  Ive never had anything quite like this beer, which made it so interesting to me.

16.9oz bottle, frome Capones (Norristown, PA). Pours hazy deep amber, almost brown, with a moderate sized tan head. Smoky, nutty, bittersweet chocolate aroma. Fairly full bodies. Rich, smoky, ashy flavor, with some spice (is that the juniper?) and mild bitterness. Dry, smoky, woody finish. interesting.

Bottle - pours a hazy garnet with a massive fluffy tan head that gushes over the top of the glass on a moderate pour.  After waiting for the foam to subside a bit, the aroma is roasted grain, slightly smoky and an earthy hoppy scent.  The flavor is initially sweet and malty then becomes smoky with coffee and berry flavors with the juniper present in the finish along with light yeasty notes. Medium body with crazy carbonation.  Unique brew and not over done in any facet except carbonation in this sample.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 2009-12-03, 6.5% ABV, 6-5-6-3-12=32Beautiful red-amber color. I remembered a better beer; this one has some ashes in the aroma and even more in the flavor; there is a light smoke aroma; the flavor has a quite good caramel and a light smoke touch; correct bitterness. Theres some light spiceness, maybe the juniper; it just makes it a bit weirder, without making it better. The dryness of the ashes is disturbing.2007-07-26, 6% ABV, 7-4-8-4-16=39Cloudy brown color; persistent head, as the bottle keeps erupting foam. The aroma is a nice mix of smoked malt and German hops. Good body structure, malty taste, with strong smoke character, plus strong and aromatic hopping, and light yeast taste at the end. Very good.
Brown body, tan head.  Aroma is smokey, ham, coffee, roasty.  Taste is smokey, roasty, oak.  Pretty nice mild smokiness.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours turbid ruddy muddy brown with 3-finger off-white head and floaties.  The aroma is huge campfire smoke, charred malt, slight hop, berry, and peppery notes.  The palate is medium in heft, providing flavor notes of smoked caramel malt, burning wood, and slight berry and hop notes.  Not quite as balanced as the Schlenkerla offerings, this one is nonetheless very good.

500ml bottle.  Pours out a dark red color with a tan colored head on it.  Smell is smoked, not much hops at all, some sweet flavors, but mostly it is pretty smoky smelling.  Taste is also smoked, but not enough to be unpleasant.  Fruit and plum notes become more abound as the beer warms.  It is actually really good, and it went great with a cigar.  Very nice stuff.
22 oz. Bottle sampled. Pours hazy amber with a small beige head. Aroma of smoke, caramel, and fruit. The flavor is caramel, smoke, sweet, fruit, and spices. Good brew.

Great score!  Jackson wrote about this type of brew ages ago and I dont think Ive ever tried one.  Slightly hazy dark amber.  Smokey, slightly yeasty aroma with lots of woody, earthy nuance.  Quite spritzy...seems the carbonation has gotten away from them...so as the smokey flavours unfold the body thins out and the malts dissipate from the palate in a wave of bubbles.  After that point, its all over.  Theres some fruit, a rich yeastiness (too rich, evidently) some burned fruit and heavy wood.

Woah. This is a weird one. Pours a murky reddish brown color with a rather large slightly off white head. Aroma has some earthy smokey hints. The flavor is tangy with lots ashy muddiness. This is  weird but I sorta like it!

500ml bottle. Cloudy reddish copper with a huge head. Good retention. Aroma is smoky wood covering everything else. Taste is smoke with dark fruit and brown sugar. Medium bodied. Somewhat chalky. Creative beer.

Umm, belgian smoked beer, mix two of my favorites and ill have seconds. Pours cloudy amber with a thin white head. Sweet delicious smokiness, not like cheap ash tray, but more like fine cigar aroma, earthy throughout. Great balance between the fruity malts and the smoked finish, nothing uneven, just a good display of sharing the responsibilities of making me happy. I hope I can get my hands on bottles of this in the Portland market soon.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense light brown head. Sweetness, fruits, light spice and smoke in the aroma. Flavour is smoked as well. Has notes of bacon, light fruits and spice. Quite complex. Good balance. Medium bodied. Grassy and smoky end.

Tried at SIB. I was really looking forward to this one, and it was indeed a unique and worthy beer for the SIB lineup. Lots of smoke in the aroma and tatse mixed with a bit of sour fruit. A little oakey and earthy. I really enjoyed this; but smoke might be my favorite taste in a beer.

Dark copper with a big and firm slightly off-white head. Wood and smoke dominates the aroma, which also has a bit of dark fruit and caramel. I get some juniper after swirling a few times. Dry and bitter flavour with the juniper delivering a gin-like tinge. All in all its a very good beer and a traditional ale of the kind that makes you believe in the good stories of old tradition. The smoke and juniper makes it a bit heavy to drink though, so dont buy a sixpack for Saturday night...

[Taster  Seattle International Beerfest]
Dark brown in color with a thin head.  Woody and malty aroma. The flavor was that of a traditional ale.  Medium body with a slight oxidized flavor.  I am sure this bottle has had to travel.  Not bad for a nice small brewery.

750 at the Seattle International Beerfest. Pours cloudy brown with very thin tan head. Pronounced sour smoky nose with some caramel there too. Medium body, tingly carb, forward flavors. Bold mid-palate; lots of smoke and sour, near-bacon notes. Rich and earthy. Clean enough finish with some ashy cling.

500 ml bottle. Reddish copper colour. Throws a tall fine-laced off-white head. Head clings to the glass. Rich piney and floral smoked malt aroma. Very balanced. Hops enhance the complexity. Smells absolutely wonderful.  Crisp bitter flavours and a lively fine carbonation at first. There is quite a bit of malt flavours there, but they drown a bit in the rather bold bitterness. The bitterness stems from both hops and juniper berries I think. Still there is a lot of flavour and a little complexity in there. Long lasting bitter aftertaste. Overall this beer has a fantastic aroma, but it doesnt really carry on to the flavour and aftertaste, both which is dominated by the bitterness. That said, this is a very characterful and rich beer that deserves to be inbibed.

Bottle (St. Urhos, Helsinki)
Lovely rich reddy-brow with a doughy creamy head, which stays as you drink. Sweet aroma, smells of gin. Enormous, but well-balanced bitter taste, resolves to smoky burnt malt. Burps juniper! Nice!

Bottle bought at the Matstreif 2007 festival in Oslo. Hazy copper with a big yellowish head. Sweet and smokey aroma, maybe a hint of sourness. Flavours are mainly smokey and sweet with some fruit. Medium to full body. Interesting and quite unique on the Norwegian beer scene.
Cloudy amber colour with a beige head. Malty, fruity aroma with a light smoky note. Malty, sweet and light fruity flavor with a dry and smoky finish.
Bottle at KØ07. Teaish, smoky aroma. Cloudy red/brown colour. OK sourness and a hint of smoke to the flavour. Horseblanket and powerful hop flavour. Good mouthfeel. Nice.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 (Bottle 50 cl) Clear, warm amber golden - no head at all. Lightly smoked nose. Medium body with a fairly high carbonation and notes of burned caramel and smoke. Dry and very hoppy finish - perhaps the juniper also adds to the bitterness. 130507

Bottlded. Hazy amber with a low white foam. Smokey, grassy and a bit nutty aroma with touches of licorice and alcohol. Smokey and salty flavour with notes of toffee and grass. Medium, spritsy body. Toasted bread, grass and peer in the flat aftertaste.

Bottled. Dark, hazy, amber colour with mediumsized off-white head. Aroma is fruits, grass and some spices. Also a big note of conifer. Flavour is slightly smoked conifer, malts and some hops. A very wellbalanced and pleasant beer.

Københavnske Øldage 07. Bottle. The color is beautiful orange-copper and the head is huge and creamy. The aroma has notes of licorice, spice, fruit and a light smoke. The flavour is spicy with notes of malt, smoke, juniper berries, tannic acid, and its a very untraditional and exciting beer. 2196

Bottle.
Muddy orange coloured with an off white head.
Light roasted aroma of smoke and burnt wood.
Light roasted flavour of hops with notes of smoke.
Hoppy finish.
Bottle at Københavnske Øldage 2007. Clear brown - offwhite head. Smokey, malty, caramel, sweetness, light fruity, dark chokolate, dry, light wood.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Bottle at Danska Öldager 2007.
Dark brown clear colour, with flat head.
Aroma of citus,dry hopy nose,dark chocolate,smokey,and som fruityness.
Flavor is: coffee,dark chocolate,tar,dry roasty finish. Medium body, medium finish. Nice!!

Hazy orange brown body, beige small bubbled head; Quite big pleasantly smoked nose, behind the smoke there is a rose like sweetness, licorice and some spices that I doent recognize; Huge soft carbonation, a little dry on a otherwise very soft textured balanced bitter body; Long bitter finish, slightly dry with lots of aroma, more balanced then nose but very similar.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Hazy medium to dark amber color with a average frothy good lacing mostly lasting off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wood, smoke, vanilla. Initial flavor is moderate bitter and light bitter, middel flavor is moderate sweet and bitter, finish flavor is moderate sweet and heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, ttexture is oily, carbonation is soft. Nice beer ;o))

Bottle. A hazy dark amber beer with a big beige head. The aroma is dusty, smoked and have some wood, the taste is a bit smoked, to much for my taste, but there is also some fruitiness to it. Medium body with a smoked finish.

Bottled at Københavnske Øldage.  Mahogany colour, small head. Dryish woody nose. Lightly smokey and roasty with some hazelnuts. Medium bodied with mellow, somewhat syrupy mouthfeel.Dryish finish with low bitterness. Nice flavour, but lacking in malt character.
CBF07 sample. Pours unfiltered orange with a white head. Aroma of smoke and coal. Flavour is smoked and slight malty. Finish is bitter and dry.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2007 Bottle. A really good beer. This is very smoky, but not overpowering. The beech-smoke is evident from aroma to the last swallow and blends very well with the juniper berries. The use of the german wheat strain is a wise choice. It adds some interesting fruity notes that brings the beer an extra dimension. And it also brings the beer closer to the traditional Norwegian ales that often uses farm-strains that give bavarian or belgian-like fruitiness.
Tap. Hazy reddish with a little yellowish head. Aroma is smoky and sweet. Flavour is oaky, sweet, light and very smoky. Too much smoke for me.

Really nice supprised this one, been looking for a brew with smoked and tar noted that isnt a rauchbeer and isnt a porter/stout. Deep orange hazy look with a light orange head, nice. Clear aroma of bunfire and tar, also very nice. Plesant palate and fruity/sticky bitter finish from the juniper berries, again very nice.

Average fizzy off-white head that mostly lasted. Hazy orange colour. Fair lacing in glass. Aroma of wood, liquorish, smoke, caramel and some hoppy notes as well. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Flavour was sweet with light hops bitterness. Nice sweet and somewhat smoky finish.
Helsinki Beer Festival 2007. Wow! Extremely piney, fruity aroma, some pineapple and mango. Dark honey colour. Taste tar, smoke, pine, forest, summer...aaah... smooth stuff!

Smoky, a little sourness. Dominated by the smoke, but there is a nice aroma from the juniper berries, too. A very interesting beer, about time someone used old Norwegian home brewing as inspiration for a commercial beer. A bit short in the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Big yellowish head. Hazy dark red brownish body. Smoky juniper aroma, very harmonic and strong, with mint notes. Taste is the same smoky juniper, quite sharp and refreshing. Some roasty, chocolatey notes in the background. Dry, smoky aftertaste with long, lingering smoke taste. An excellent beer! Strong character, very original, highly drinkable. The smoke and juniper combination is a real winner. (0.5l bottle at Pingvinen.)

(Bottled) Opaque dark amber with a medium, foamy head. Quite smoky and earthy pine-woody aroma. Fresh, pine-hoppy flavor with some smoke and fruit. Medium-bodied with quite low carbonation.  Once again: interesting and pleasant, but wont probably buy again.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is dry, juniper, hop, caramel. Flavour is hop, caramel, fruit, dry, juniper, roasted Light bitter finish. Pleasent beer.

500 ml bottle. Slightly hazy red-brown body with a decent beige head. The aroma is extremely complex, starting with juniper and wood, light roasted malt with a discreet touch of smoke and yeast. The smoke is more present in the flavor, together with juniper, bitter fruit (maybe juniper berry?), yeast, roasted malt and some bitterness. The very pleasant juniper taste remains in the finish.

500 ml bottle, bottle conditioned. Brewed with juniper and smoked malts. Dark brown colour, creamy head. The aroma is dominated by smoke (beechwood?) and oak. The flavour is very smokey and woody, with notes of hickory and tar. Dry finish.

Bottled. I were lucky enough to have a pre-release taste at a beer-dinner where Haandbryggeriet kindly donated a crate of this one and the other new beer, Dark Force. It poured golden-brown, almost completely clear, with a nice beige head, leaving nice lacings as well. The wooden aromas started escaping the beer immediately, and was followed by some smoke, roastyness, juniper-fruityness and bitterness. It has a smoked and woody flavor, with juniper, roasted malt, bitterness, fruityness and something reminding med of the smell of the sleeper on a railroad track. It has a medium to full body and a long bitter finish. Theres a distinct juniper note in the finish as well. Its a quite complex beer with lots of flavors and aromas from a Norwegian conifer forest. My favourite from Haandbryggeriet. (070317)
